intro: Gilia capitata subsp. pedemontana, commonly known as the Sierra gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Mirbeliaceae family and is characterized by its showy, clustered flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils in mountainous regions, often at elevations between 1,500 and 3,000 meters. It has hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. This species is often found in open habitats such as meadows and slopes, where it thrives in full sun.
